document.title: A Medical Humanities Course: A Pertinent Pause on the Medical Beat

author.institution: University of Missouri-Kansas City School of Medicine

document.abstract: This article summarizes the findings of one ethnographic study and demonstrates that, by emphasizing self- reflection and discussion, an interdisciplinary literature and medicine course provides medical students a brief but important, time for retrospection.
document.publication-title: The Journal of the Assembly for Expanded Perspectives on Learning

field.name: acknowledgements
field.value: Kathleen Welch is an Assistant Clinical Professor at the University of Missouri-Kansas City School of Medicine. Her most recent publication, “Writing for Literature and Medicine,” appears in the book Approaches to Teaching Literature and Medicine (MLA, January 2000).
